ResponsesInList.Title: Convert Recorded Audio
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, I have a recording test, and the output is in MP3 format. However, my hosting server does not support playing MP3 files. Can I change the output to another format, such as AAC or WAV? based on this pic, i can't play the mp3 file.. but i can play another format (aac,wav)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Convert Recorded Audio
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Mohammad, I do not think your hosting provider is the problem. MP3 will work fine. You are using the Poodll filter. But Moodle also has a filter called "MultiMedia Plugins" filter. Probably they are both processing the same MP3 file, and so they are conflicting. Try this: Move the Poodll filter higher in the order of filters. So that it works first. This should prevent the conflict. Do this at: Site administration -> Plugins -> Filters -> Manage filters Did that work? Finally ... you should use the Cloud Poodll Question. It is much simpler than the Poodll Recording question. And it does not need the Poodll filter. It is here: https://moodle.org/plugins/qtype_cloudpoodll

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Convert Recorded Audio
ResponsesInList.Text: Sure! Here’s the updated response: Hello, Yes, you may think so, but I also didn’t initially think they were blocking MP3 files. However, the MP3 file is indeed blocked by my hosting provider, and this has been confirmed by them: "Good morning Mr./Ms. Mohammad Rizki, This is Goldan here. Regarding the issue, MP3 files are blocked according to our Terms of Service. We recommend using embedding methods, such as uploading to object storage or SoundCloud and embedding the link." As a result, I am unable to download or access the MP3 files recorded by the students. Because I have already subscribed to this hosting for a year, I have had to clone Moodle to another hosting provider to access the students' audio recordings. That’s why I’ve been searching for a solution to allow the students' recordings to be in a different audio format, other than MP3. I have also read about the Poodll filter order and have already moved it to the top, but the issue persists. Thank you!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Convert Recorded Audio
ResponsesInList.Text: HI Mohammad, I see. Do you have a Poodll subscription? If so please contact us at https://support.poodll.com We can share specific information then, and it will be faster. Cloud Poodll does not store the files on the Moodle server. It stores them in the cloud, and just the links are placed in the Moodle site. So it is what your hosting company is recommending you to do. If you can install the Cloud Poodll Question, and set your Poodll API user and secret in the plugin admin settings, then I think that it will work. Please try.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Convert Recorded Audio
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you for your response and for clarifying how Cloud Poodll operates. As you may know, I am currently trying out the trial version, and it has been working wonderfully so far. I must say, it is quite impressive and has effectively addressed my needs. For now, I plan to continue exploring the trial version further. I truly appreciate the innovative solution Poodll provides, and I look forward to seeing how it performs over time.

ResponsesInList.Title: Poodll Video Easy
ResponsesInList.Text: This is a discussion topic dedicated to questions comments and discussion about the Video Easy filter . VideoEasy  replaces links to media files, with  html5 players. Primarily intended for html 5 video, it will also work for audio, youtube or rss links. The Video Easy filter uses templates to support multiple players, and allows the user to add new players or customize existing ones, all from the Video Easy filter settings pages.

ResponsesInList.Title: Gery's Question
ResponsesInList.Text: If I add more than one sound (I use mp3 files), only the first one is showing. If I add second file after the first one, it's not showing it or any other content after that sound. I don't think it's the problem with the template because I've tried all of them, even made a custom one, and the result is the same. If it was just one template I would say that it must be a very old template that couldn't handle multiple MP3s. But if its all templates than it might be a case of "double filtering." Where two media plugins try to handle the same media file, basically causing the sky to fall in and hell to freeze over. Try turning off Multimedia Plugins filter temporarily. Does that solve it? If so turn it back on, and disable handling of the mp3 file extension by the media player that Multi Media Plugins filter is using.  Or move VideoEasy filter higher in the order of filters at : site admin -> plugins -> filters --> manage filters

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gery's Question
ResponsesInList.Text: Dear Justin, How can I add Twice Player template to Video Easy exist template. Thanks
role: Picture of Ms. Suaad Al Salti

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Gery's Question
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Suaad I have attached the twice player template bundle to this post. Drag it over the green "bundle" box on an empty VideoEasy template settings page. Then save.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Video Easy
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, Just installed VideoEasy and setup a template for JWPlayer. All seems to be working well with my basic test, thanks! However I was wondering if it's possible to have more than one source URL for a video stream? E.g. mpd and m3u8? I see there is reference to a Multi Source Video template on the GitHub ReadMe but it looks like this has been removed. Cheers, Ryan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Video Easy
ResponsesInList.Text:
Yes. Its pretty easy to do. You just add the extra source in the body of the template. As long as all the video files are in the same directory then something like this would work. NB I used the URLSTUB variable. You can see more of those handy variables at: https://support.poodll.com/en/support/solutions/articles/19000083258 
```text
<video id="@@AUTOID@@" controls="controls" width="@@WIDTH@@" height="@@HEIGHT@@">


  <source src="@@URLSTUB@@.mp4" type="video/mp4" />


  <source src="@@URLSTUB@@.webm" type="video/webm" />


  Your browser does not support HTML5.


</video>
```

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Video Easy
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks Justin - that's helpful.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Video Easy
ResponsesInList.Text: Sometimes, despite video easy enabled in a course, I would like to prevent the plugin to kick in on a specific link. Is there a way to do this manually? Like assigning a class "no-videoeasy-plugin"?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Video Easy
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Justin, I was wondering how to enable the filter for videos uploaded a File resource (Embedded setting). Even if the filter is positioned above the Multimedia plugins filter, the Video Easy does not seem to apply the template to the video. Thanks

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Video Easy
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Philippe, Yeah, filters do not always seem to work on those. If they did, we could do something. What I have done in the past is add JS script to the page which hunts down uploaded .wav/m4a extension files and then renders those in a popup player if the file link is clicked. If you are able to tinker with js/html to show mp4 or other video files, you could modify that for this task. Probably not the solution you were looking for. But if you want to try ... You will need the Generico filter for this. You need to create a template from the bundle file (popupwavplayer.txt) that I have attached here. Just drag the bundle file over the green "bundle" button an empty Generico filter template page in the templates area of the Generico filter settings. And save changes. In safari that drag and drop might now work. In that case use Chrome. ​ The template needs to be inserted as a widget on  page where the attachements are. You might add it to an html block that shows on that page. After you created the template , it should be possible to just paste the following text into block text area. You have to be a little careful when pasting these things that html artifacts do not come too e.g font or span tags. These can break it. (The safest way is really to type it by hand.) {GENERICO:type="popupwavplayer"} The Generico filter bundle is attached.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Video Easy
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks a lot Justin for confirming it is trickier than expected. I'll look into it when I get the chance.

ResponsesInList.Title: Privacy (Poodll Cloud)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello, We are planning to use Poodll and we are specially interested in automatic phonetic correction which is a great feature. I understand the technology is based on Amazon software and data are stoured in the cloud. Can you tell me if this data (students voices) is acced by third parties, Amazon for instance, where the servers are (ie under what laws) /what kind of privacy policiy is applied? Thank you very much for your help!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Privacy (Poodll Cloud)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Ulrike The data that is sent and stored on Amazon is just voice data. Usernames, email addresses and even the Moodle userid are not stored there. You have a choice of servers, Tokyo, USA (north east), Sydney, Dublin. If you use the Dublin server then it is the EU and GDPR applies. Poodll has a privacy policy, here: https://support.poodll.com/en/support/solutions/articles/19000079274-poodll-user-data-and-gdpr Note also that Poodll supports the Moodle Privacy API so you can manage your requirements using that. I hope that helps

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Privacy (Poodll Cloud)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Justin, Yes, indeed - thank you very much for your answer (and the good news)! Ulrike

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Warning -dumb question

ResponsesInList.Title: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi guys We have the scenario of reasonably limited server disk space, and we will be conducting daily marking of audio/video assessments. Once marked, we do not wish to keep the audio/video files, and we wish to remove these from the server. Can anyone tell us the easiest methodology to achieve this? Kind Regards Lee

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lee Right now we just leave it up to Moodle to manage those files. To remove them in the way that you want, I think you would need to delete the assignment that they had been submitted to. Or create a seperate course for each assignment and 'reset" the course when ready. J

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin Thanks. We will have thousands of students a year submitting to this particular assignment, so there's no option for us to delete the assignment itself. I want to be able to delete the file submission of the student once it's been graded. There doesn't appear to be a way to do this in the UI - even for a site admin. What path on the webserver does PoodLL place the uploads? Regards Lee

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: The files all go into the Moodle file system, which is a black box really. Its not an easy thing at all to find them and delete them via the OS file system. You need to use the Moodle APIs to delete them. Right now we do not have a 'delete all' Poodll files feature. We just let Moodle handle the deleting, when the time is right. But actually it is on the roadmap. Just no promise of when

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin So we've been running PoodLL for a few months now happily collecting and grading videos from hundreds of students. This morning Moodle crashed with a server partition full error, and I'm fairly convinced it's PoodLL's video storage that is the main culprit. You: "Right now we just leave it up to Moodle to manage those files." I just don't understand this. I don't see how Moodle actually manages anything. It just stores the files in its "black box". We don't have unlimited storage (who does?). I need to understand how much disk space is being consumed by PoodLL's video store, and I need to be able to actively manage them to ensure our production server doesn't fill up and crash. Your advice/guidance here would be much appreciated. Regards Lee

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lee I am really sorry about the trouble. You will need about 9MB for each minute of video. So you do need to make sure you have ample disk space. The key thing here is that Moodle manages the activity(quiz, activity, forum etc) and by extension the files associated with that activity. So to remove files, you need to remove the attempts or submissions or posts that contain them. Moodle then deletes the files or moves them to trash. The actual restoration of file space (true deletion of file) takes about 4 days for some reason. If a file is no longer necessary then presumably neither is the activity/post/submission containing it. So that really is the best way to manage the files. Poodll could do better in reporting about files, I agree. But its just not a good idea for Poodll to try to remove files that are contained in activities . I know that you are using assignments and students have relatively short enrolment periods. Since Moodle does not offer the ability to delete assignment submissions individually, my suggestion for pruning files is to have two courses and alternate them. When one course no longer has users enroled, then reset the course. This will remove the files associated. You can be specific and reset only the assignments in the course if that is better.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin Thanks for the response, and the ideas for possible management. The two courses idea is a good one but doesn't work for us as we never have the situation of zero users enrolled. At this point I have been able to build a report to see the culprit files. As expected, they are already consuming a significant portion of our overall server allocation. This seems to be exacerbated by the system seeming to store multiple versions of the same file - see below: We've managed to clear out about 30GB by removing no-longer-needed backups, but I know that within 1-2 months we will be back here again and will either need to commission more server space, or... I don't know! We really need Cloud PoodLL and the ability to have these files stored in a separately managed repository (e.g. AWS bucket). Any news in this regard? Kind Regards Lee

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lee Those multiple file entries are a bit of a red herring (fortunately). Moodle only stores the file data once, though it has separate file entries in the database . One of the fields you have in that table is the contenthash field. For each of those files it will be the same contenthash, and that is how Moodle ties them all together (draft files and permanent files). CloudPoodll is working well and we have built the new CloudPoodll assignment, and another plugin on top of it. The Cloud Poodll assignment is in alpha/beta now. I think we can get it to you in a fortnight.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin Thanks for that - I've altered my reporting to exclude the duplicate database entries to get a more correct representation. Very good news on the Cloud PoodLL front - I'll touch base in a couple of weeks if I don't hear from you sooner. Thanks! Kind Regards Lee

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Purging, archiving, disk space
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lee In the end I fast tracked the Cloud Poodll Assignment Submission plugin. Here it is here: https://github.com/justinhunt/moodle-assignsubmission_cloudpoodll The regular Poodll registration key is irrelevant here. This is not dependent on the Poodll filter or any other plugin. You just need a new thing called API username (thats your poodll.com username) and API secret. You can pick the API secret up at Poodll.com as described here: https://support.poodll.com/support/solutions/articles/19000083076-cloud-poodll-api-secret Hope it helps

ResponsesInList.Title: Poodll and Moodle 3.5

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll and Moodle 3.5
ResponsesInList.Text: Why would you want to disable PoodLL? They both work in my Moodle. In fact, when making audio recordings, I prefer to use PoodLL as it automatically gives me the small audio player. The new built in stuff seems to automatically give me a video sized player when it is only an audio recording.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll and Moodle 3.5
ResponsesInList.Text: Moreover, the new built in recorder is capped at 2 minutes. It also isn't usable (currently anyway) in Quiz text fields (and possibly Assignments [haven't checked personally], or feedback fields, Database activity, etc. whereas Poodll is. Poodll is still far far more versatile than the new recorder. Poodll is also far more than just a recorder even if you don't use those features.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll and Moodle 3.5
ResponsesInList.Text: Currently the Moodle built in recorders just work in the HTML editors. They won't interfere with Poodll or vice versa. If you would prefer to use those over Poodll, you can simply uninstall PoodLL Anywhere for Atto (or for TinyMCE). Its also possible to just hide individual icons, from the Poodll Anywhere site settings. If you prefer to show Poodll only to teachers, you can even adjust access to those capabilities in Moodle from Site admin->Users->Permissions->Define roles I suppose we need to have the Poodll vs Moodle built in recorders discussion soon. But for now let me just say that its really good news that Moodle has built in audio and video recording. And we are watching closely to see how users find it.  Poodll has lots to offer yet, in many areas, so its business as usual for us.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio appears to record - but produces 0KB file
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lee Numerous things can go wrong, so its hard to say straight up. Which version of the Poodll filter are you using? Knowing that helps. One obvious thing that can cause this, is when your microphone does not capture any audio. This can be because you don't have a mic, or because you have not granted permission to the browser (or Flash) to use the mic. It can also sometimes be because your browser refuses to allow access to the mic . This can happen if your site is not on HTTPS, with Google Chrome and Mozilla Firefox . You can try recording at https://demo.poodll.com because this is all set up ok. If you need to test Flash, try using Internet Explorer. That should default to Flash,

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio appears to record - but produces 0KB file
ResponsesInList.Text: I have discovered the above issue is caused by Chrome blocking the use of the camera and microphone on sites using HTTP rather than HTTPS. Furthermore there is no way to alter this setting. You can read more here . I see no alternative other than to have our entire Moodle instance migrated to HTTPS. If anyone has any other comments I'd love to hear them. Hopefully this thread may help others in a similar situation. Regards Lee

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio appears to record - but produces 0KB file
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Lee Yes that is correct. Chrome and Firefox (often) block access to the cam and mic on http sites. It does not seem to be universal, though I think it will be soon. The best solution really is to move to HTTPS. There is no real reason to stay on HTTP and plenty of reasons to go to HTTPS. Many of the Cpanel based hosting providers provide free SSL now, and you can also get good free ssl from : https://letsencrypt.org/ The recorders that you see on https://demo.poodll.com are HTML5 recorders. They have skins and special purpose variants. A lot of development has gone into them, and its ongoing. But they only work on Poodll3 which is only available for Moodle 3.1 and above.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio appears to record - but produces 0KB file

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio appears to record - but produces 0KB file
ResponsesInList.Text: Just to close out this discussion, I had our whole Moodle instance converted to HTTPS, and everything started working.

ResponsesInList.Title: Poodll Recording Question behavior & feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: Is it possible to work with Poodll recording quiz questions with either of these question behaviors? Immediate Feedback Interactive with Multiple tries At the moment, I use Poodll for an activity where students record an answer to a question and then compare their recorded answer to  to a text model in generalfeedback. This is done using Deferred Feedback after answering all questions. But it would be great if students could check their answer after each question, before moving on.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Recording Question behavior & feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: I think this could work, in the same way that it is possible to hear the current submission in the assignment. But right now it doesn't do this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll Recording Question behavior & feedback
ResponsesInList.Text: In the Question itself, there is an option to include grade information, as well as general feedback to students. General feedback only appears once student has submitted the item. For example, we include a copy of our grading rubric for students to see. You could include insert the model recording here so that students can listen to it after having submitted their quiz. This feature, of course, has nothing to do with Poodll, just a normal possibility for providing feedback in Moodle.

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL support information and number of active users (long query)
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, I just see that there is now (don't really know whenit arrived) in PoodLL filter plugin a section named "PoodLL support information". I understand the use of this, to help manage problems and have them resolved sooner. In these information,  there is the "number of active users". The problem is that, to obtain this number, there is (i suppose) a calculation made from the log table, and this calculation can be very very long. Moreover, it generates a very big load on the server . On my plateforms, it has taken up to 5 minutes for the biggest one When, has an admin, you open a setting or information page, you expect to have it open (nearly) instantly, and not to have to wait several minutes. I really think that this calculation should not be made when you open this page, but on (specific) demand, with a big warning , or by cron, at a moment where the server is less used. Séverin

ResponsesInList.Title: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi, Does anyone know of a way that I can set up a PoodLL quiz question that students can self-grade. Student reads a question Student records an answer with PoodLL Student compares their own answer to a model answer in "general Feedback" Student grades their answer (so the Teacher doesn't have to") Steps 1 through 3 are obviously already standard quiz steps. The fourth is important for me since the objective of the exercise I'm trying to build is the checking of the answer (and not necessarily the answering). I realize this is probably a general Moodle question rather than PoodLL specific, but since I got no answer in the general Moodle forums, I thought maybe another PoodLL user had experienced the same need.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Daniel, It depends on which version of Moodle you are using and even then would need testing to make sure you have things set up right. I have tried this with an essay question and a PoodLL question in a quiz, and it works. Create the quiz, then in Quiz administration click on Permissions . Scroll down to Activity: Quiz and find Grade quizzes manually . Click the + and add Student . In my testing, students were able to see and grade only their own quiz. The teacher was able to see and grade them all.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
ResponsesInList.Text: It works! Thank you. I've been trying to find out how to do this for ages. I'm very happy.  This will add a great deal of value to the activities I want to use it in and for the students on my course. Thank you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Off hand, I can't remember which version of Moodle it was where they gave us the capability to modify the permissions for individual activities like this. The nice thing is the same "trick" of changing permissions for an activity works with other activities too, but you do have to be VERY CAREFUL as they do not necessarily limit a student to seeing and grading ONLY their own entries. Just as a personal reminder, on the few occasions that I've used this trick, I have added something to the activity name and description, such as "Self graded" just to make sure I don't accidentally duplicate and use it when and where I shouldn't.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Student self-grading poodll quiz questions
ResponsesInList.Text: Thanks. That's a useful tip. It will also help students differentiate between quizzes that are self-graded and auto-graded.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL does not appear in Feedback comments
ResponsesInList.Text: That is intentional. Just like you cannot add images there with the insert-image-file-picker. Instead there is the Poodll Feedback plugin where you can leave audio/video feedback - the poodll file doesn't appear in the user report directly, so in the assignment text area feedback box we would leave a message that says something like 'click on your assignment to review your teacher's audio feedback.' This has worked well for us this past school year. Another thing you could do is direct link to an externally stored audio/video file (in the assignment feedback text box) but that can be a little time consuming if your looking to do that regularly.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL does not appear in Feedback comments
ResponsesInList.Text: Its just like John said. There is no file area to store files, so Poodll just hides itself to stop people getting the wrong idea that it would work. So your best option is to use the Poodll assignment feedback plugin.

ResponsesInList.Title: Generic Question about Poodll Repository (and repos more generally)
ResponsesInList.Text: Background Context - Cleaning up LOTS of old and unused stuff, and otherwise simplifying the installation. I've come to nearly the end of my list and I was looking at datafield for Poodll (we don't use the database activity for anything) so I added it to my remove list. Then I got to Poodll Repository. Poodll repository. I'm trying to wrap my head around what it is and exactly how it works. It is basically just allowing a folder to add files to/take from that get stored there? I see in the settings it says 6 site wide instances, but, zero category or course instances since it isn't enabled in any courses. We use Poodll for submissions with the assignment activity, qtype for the quiz activity, as well as the necessary Poodll filter to render the audio player/recorder. My ultimate question is can I uninstall the poodll repository plugin without it affecting the aforementioned assignment submission, qtype, and filter in any way? I totally get this is due to my lack of understanding of what the repositories are/how they work but I appreciate any advice anyone has to offer .

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Generic Question about Poodll Repository (and repos more generally)
ResponsesInList.Text: The repository is the original way of getting files into the Moodle file system for use in the current activity. For example, if you go to add a picture into an html area, the popup dialog allows you to enter a URL , or to "browse repositories"(usually) Once you are in the repositories area , you have options to: upload a file choose from server /recent/private files area (optionally) get a file from google drive (optionally) get a file from wikimedia etc Its not just html areas either. The little file attachments drag and drop area, that you see under forum post forms and in other places, is also powered by the repository system. Regarding Poodll, mostly you do not need the Poodll repository any more. Poodll Anywhere for Atto and TinyMCE allow you to record/draw into a text area faster than going via the repository system. But you might need it sometimes, eg when you only have a file attachments area. Removing it won't affect anything else in Poodll. So you can safely remove it I think. Repository intances actually need to be setup, so if you did not do that then its doubtful you are using it anyway.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Generic Question about Poodll Repository (and repos more generally)

I've never used them and I don't think any one has ever used them. My guess is the previous admin simply installed all of the Poodll mods regardless of whether they were used or not. I see what you mean that if the editor doesn't have Poodll Anywhere, you would need to use the Repository short cut (provided it's there) through the file manager. And if there is no editor available, then the file attachments area is the only way to access it. Adding it to my remove list . Thanks for clarifying.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Generic Question about Poodll Repository (and repos more generally)

ResponsesInList.Title: Poodll video created with ipad not showing in computer browsers
ResponsesInList.Text:
A very good afternoon to you all and thank you for your support of Poodll. I'm wondering if anyone might be able to help me. Some students created a Poodll video with their ipads which converted properly and was visible when the students posted it to a forum (Moodle 3.2). I saw the video playing. However, now it isn't visible. All that shows in the forum window is "upfile_468814434.mov". In the html I can see "

" which means it should be showing doesn't it? If someone could point me to what I'm doing wrong and how to fix it I'd be most grateful. Kind regards, Eric

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll video created with ipad not showing in computer browsers
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eric As a super Poodll 3 guy you can, and probably should, send support requests via the contact form at https://poodll.com/contact or send email directly. The reason is that in Poodll 3 there is a support info file that you can generate. That tells me all your versions and settings, and it speeds things up. Find that at: site admin -> plugins -> filters -> poodll -> support info ( I think its probably best not to attach it to forum posts. ) To answer your question. It sounds like "cloud recording" is off. In that case the mov file has not been sent to the Poodll cloud conversion service. So it is stuck a mov file. Try turning on "cloud recording" on the Poodll filter general settings page. This is really the best thing to do. You could maybe play ,mov file back as is.  As long as the player selected was good with mov files. You could try the Media Element Video player in Poodll. This page explains how to set up Video JS, but the principles are the same for Media Element Audio. https://poodll.com/poodll-3-docs/video-js/ Finally there is a Poodll App these days. Read about that here, https://poodll.com/poodll-3-docs/using-the-poodll-mobile-app/ That makes it easier to record audio/video off iOS devices. But it also works best with cloud recording. So you should have that enabled.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio/video file remove from course but file still exist in MoodleData folder and info in Database
ResponsesInList.Text: If the files are stored in the Moodle file system, using the Moodle files API then Moodle should take care of deleting old files. This should happen periodically when the Moodle cron job is run.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio/video file remove from course but file still exist in MoodleData folder and info in Database
ResponsesInList.Text: Thank you Justin for quick reply. Question is: How Moodle will understand which file to be deleted and which file should keep?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Audio/video file remove from course but file still exist in MoodleData folder and info in Database
ResponsesInList.Text: Each file is stored in a file area that is associated with a context . So for example, when an assignment submission is deleted, any files in file areas associated with that context and item id are deleted (or marked for deletion). So if you save files in the way that Moodle expects , Moodle will handle all that stuff for you.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Error uploading audio files
ResponsesInList.Text: Well from all that it sounds like audio is not making it through to the recorder in the first place. ie It is not being captured. This is because: i) no sound can be played back from the audio recorder itself ii) the video recorder records video, but not sound This means that it is likely to be something specific to your pc. If it were a permissions issue, your video would not be captured. So this makes me think that you either have no microphone or your microphone is off or your machine has multiple audio capture devices and the wrong one is being used. If you right click the recorder and choose "settings" or "properties" you should be able to see the audio capture devices that Flash has detected. You can also see when audio is picked up by the mic. If you play around there, can you make something work?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 回复: Cannot hear the audio quiz attempt
ResponsesInList.Text: The reason for this is probably that the placeholder audio file is being cached by your browser. When you use the standard multimedia plugins filter this is an issue. You have two options here i) enable the PoodLL filter and set it to handle mp3 files, then it will work as expected. https://poodll.com/poodll-3-docs/handling-mp3/ OR ii) set the mp3 recorder to upload directly to Moodle and bypass the cloud. To do that, under site admin -> plugins -> filters -> poodll -> general settings under "MP3 Recorder settings" check "no cloud". This works because there is no placeholder file.

ResponsesInList.Title: 回复: Re: 回复: Cannot hear the audio quiz attempt
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, Thanks so much for your help. I have tried both methods i) did not work but should I turn off the standard multimedia plugin to make it work? ii) worked but  by turning off the cloud does this mean that we cannot use the recording function on the IOS app in the future?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: 回复: Re: 回复: Cannot hear the audio quiz attempt
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Vicky Regarding i) setting up PoodLL to handle audio mp3: Moodle runs pages through each of the enabled filters in turn. So the Multimedia plugins filter(MMP) needs to run after the PoodLL filter. Otherwise MMP will make an audio player and leave nothing left for PoodLL to process. So on the page: site admin -> plugins -> filters -> manage filters move PoodLL higher than MMP in the list. Disabling MMP will also work. And maybe its simpler. The only proviso here is that YouTube links are handled by MMP. So you would lose that. PoodLL can also handle YouTube links, just as you set up mp3 handling, you need to set up YouTube handling. The player template/preset is Youtube lightbox, but I will add a few more options shortly. Regarding ii) selecting "no cloud" with the mp3 recorder, This will have no effect on the mobile app or the other recorders. (at least not in the latest version). The mobile app is looking good but its still a few weeks away J

ResponsesInList.Text: Susan What is your version of the PoodLL filter? And which recorder are you using? It sounds like the mp3 recorder. That is more suited to shorter recordings, and over 2 - 3 minutes is not so reliable. On PoodLL3 it should work a bit better if you are using cloud recording. J

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll upload
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, The filter is v. 2.8.5 (build 2015121106).   I see there is a newer version available, but once the semester starts we don't like to mess with our Moodle setup unless absolutely necessary.  Would updating to 2.8.6 make a difference in performance? Susan

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll upload
ResponsesInList.Text: No it would not make a difference. 2.8.6 fixed a bug with some html5 widgets licensing but not with recording or uploading. Is there any common factor relating students whose recordings fail? Some of the common problems are i) check the permissions on /filter/poodll/poodllfilelib. php They should be 644 or 664. Sometimes they get messed up when you upgrade. This would cause all mp3 recordings to fail. ii) Try recording tiny small recordings, do they work? If so, a) check your max upload size for the course you are using b) check if suhosin is enabled on your php. This and apache mod_security can both interfere with the upload. iii) If you look in your browser console , there will probably be an error after a failed upload. You might find it on the "network" tab of the console, in the request to poodllfilelib.php Seeing that error would help

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Install red5 server
ResponsesInList.Text: The files are stored in the Moodle data directory in a directory structure that humans can't work with. The actual paths to the files in that directory should not be used and its practically impossible anyway. Instead use the files api and specify the context , component, file area, itemid and filename of the file to retrieve it. If you look around the poodllfilelib.php the code should help you figure it out, and you could add hooks in there to save the file elsewhere or to save the id of the file to your own database table for retrieval later. I am afraid that you will just have to learn how to use the Moodle files api for this.

ResponsesInList.Title: Usability Issues with PoodLL
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello we have just installed a number of PoodLL plugins on our moodle development environment in hopes of replacing nanogong and have seen some weirdness. We are running moodle 3.0.5+ on RHEL 6 with postgres DB We have installed the following PoodLL plugins: Filter ( 2.8.6(Build 2016061600)) Recording ( 2.6.0(Build 2015121100)) Assignment Submissions ( 1.5.9 (Build 2015121101)) Feedback ( 1.0.6 (Build 2015121101)) I noticed a number of warnings in the error log: [Wed Aug 17 16:42:40 2016] [error] [client x.x.x.x] File does not exist: /ROOT-DIRECTORY/moodle/mod/assign/skinvolumemeter.png, referer: https://SERVERNAME/moodle/mod/assign/view.php [Wed Aug 17 16:42:40 2016] [error] [client x.x.x.x] File does not exist: /ROOT-DIRECTORY/moodle/mod/assign/plainskinbackground.png, referer: https://SERVERNAME/moodle/mod/assign/view.php Is there some configuration issues we missed? Also, when we attempted to submit an audio assignment, the recorder would appear, the audio would be recorded and could be listened to but when submitted, the recorder showed up again on screen and the page was still loading (spinning).  I noticed a brief glance of some debug information and realized that moodle was set to debug email sending.  If I stopped the page, and went back to view the assignment, the audio was uploaded and working (blue flow player).  When I turned the debug off, it appeared to work. Also, for some reason, a tester indicated that they were unable to use the recorder but then it started working.  I know this is minimal information but is it possible that cache needed to be cleared or permissions for player needed to be accepted? Any advice would be appreciated.  If I have more additional comments, I will add them. Thanks Eric

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Usability Issues with PoodLL
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Eric Sorry for the slow reply. Those error messages about .png files can be ignored and they are annoying. I think I removed those in the latest version. The other issues are a bit hard to pin down. Sometimes debug and other output can get mixed up in what should be meaningful ajax responses and even into the recorded files themselves. Of course this shouldn't really happen but I have seen it before. I would consider this not a likely cause of the other problems you reported. There are many ways recording can fail, let me count the ways The recording timed out during upload The user's mic device is not recognized or not available The user has not given permission via various popup dialogs to access mic device The recording can't be uploaded due to bandwidth or network issues There are file permission issues on the PoodLL files There is a bug in PoodLL somewhere There is not really a problem, but the user thinks there is The file is recording ok, but its in a format that can't be played back The PoodLL filter settings are to convert with FFMPEG but ffmpeg is not set up PHP security settings, mod-security or suhosin are killing the file upload And that won't be all of them. So its a bit of a minefield at times. Its most likely a permissions, network or device issue. Try really short recordings, and see if they work. If they do, and big long ones don't, then try using the red5 audio recorder (ie not the mp3 one).

ResponsesInList.Title: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Hello Community; I am struggling to get consistent and good performance out of Poodll/Moodle specifically regarding mobile uploads of video assignments. I am evaluating Poodll in a self hosted virtual instance of Moodle, and have found that although small mobile video files under 10MB will generally upload via Poodll and play back without issue on the source device, once the file size exceeds roughly 15-20MB, then things start to fall apart. Background... My use case requires that all students will be submitting assignments via mobile device platforms, which if I understand correctly would be best served by converting submissions via FFMPEG for widest mobile platform compatibility. Therefore, I have built FFMPEG on my test server from sources, and have verified that when called from the system path, it is working correctly. I have also verified via shell command that the FFMPEG switches used on the poodll demo site are working. Therefore, I assume that the Poodll Filter settings to auto convert mobile submissions to MP4 and to use FFMPEG for the conversion are also working, although I have yet to determine how to verify this as I have not seen any entries in any server logs. Back to the problem at hand... Without FFMPEG settings enabled in the Poodll filter, files of any size, up to the server limit of 512MB, will upload from a mobile device without issue. Playback is choppy over mobile data, but plays smoothly via WiFi, suggesting that playback quality is bandwidth dependent. With FFMPEG conversion settings enabled in the Poodll filter, mobile uploads above approximately 15MB in size will cause a browser error on Chrome, or will simply never complete the upload process in Firefox . In Chrome, after selecting a mobile video larger than 15MB to upload, the progress bar never appears and within about 15 seconds Chrome will throw an "Aw, Snap! Something went wrong while displaying this webpage..." error. In Firefox, after selecting a mobile video to upload larger than 15MB, the progress bar will appear, but no indication of upload activity will be evident and the process never completes. Obviously, in both cases Mobile uploads will fail. Since it is possible to turn on the mobile upload processing error, and turn it off, by enabling and disabling the FFMPEG conversion settings in the Poodll filter, I assume that the root issue is with the filter and not my environment, but I would appreciate some other perspectives or troubleshooting  suggestions on the matter. Moodle is running on a Debian (Jesse) instance, with 2GB of RAM, 60GB HD, and PHP.INI settings that allow up tp 512MB uploads and 640MB of script memory. Regards; Michael

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Michael Make sure that transcoding is going on in the background (there is a switch for that on the settings page). This will mean that the browser won't wait for the transcoding to finish. It relies on cron to kick off the transcoding. So it won't start till cron runs. Though it does sound like the real issue is with uploading. There are settings that affect uploads on your web server. Apache mod_security and the PHP extension suhosin are two of those. I would look into that. Both of those by default limit the size and nature of uploads.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: FFMPEG Issues with Poodll/Moodle 3.0.2
ResponsesInList.Text: Sorry Michael, I will reply to your email today. I apologize for the delay. It sounds like you are hitting some sort of upload limit. The usual suspects are suhosin and mod_security. In php.ini there are also: memory_limit upload_max_filesize post_max_size Apparently the values of those should follow this pattern: upload_max_filesize =< post_max_size =< memory_limit So the simple way is to make them all the same, but upload_max_filesize should never be greater then post max_size, which should never be greater then memory_limit. I am not an expert in this, though I have learned the hard way about some of it. Another thing you might try is recording over at https://demo.poodll.com . This is using the new PoodLL3 and Amazon S3 for uploads. If that all works for you, perhaps PoodLL3 would be a good solution

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins
ResponsesInList.Text: After a fair bit of consideration I recently made the decision that PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins. i.e. it won't be free. PoodLL has had great uptake from the Moodle community and the users have been positive through the good times, and patient and understanding through trouble times. So going premium is not something I have taken likely. At its heart is the reality that PoodLL needs a lot of work to make the full transition to HTML5 and for a host of other feature improvements and better support options (incl. documentation). You can read more on an this here: http://poodll.com/?p=2107 It will be available as an annual subscription with 3 tiers of membership: i) individual teacher (aka little guy) ii) single institution/organization iii) partner The pricing and some other details are yet to be decided, but from now on there will be more no more updates published on Moodle.org or the existing GitHub repositories, other than bug and security fixes. In the past I maintained a mailing list of PoodLL users, but these days that list doesn't contain the large majority of users. So currently there is no direct way for me to communicate with the PoodLL user base.  It would be very helpful for me if as a PoodLL user you could take this quick 8 question survey. https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/63DJ529

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL 3 will be a premium set of plugins
ResponsesInList.Text: Justin, I wish you well with this.  I am sure it will be a success, and I think such developments are inevitable, with or without what we may call "official" support from MoodleHQ. On a completely different but related matter, I was reminded of the thread earlier on plugins.  I am still of the opinion that alongside the plugin/premium ecosystem we have talked about, we need a "Givealittle" style option. I found my post from 17th June here: https://moodle.org/mod/forum/discuss.php?d=314916#p1263153 I think I will give this a little bump. My view remains unchanged: " As a first off, I'd like someone to make it easy for us to "give a little" to any developer with a plugin in the database .  Quite apart from any of the complex plans and programmes you have thought about" I will watch developments with interest Justin. -Derek

I hope that you get enough institutions on board to allow you to keep the price very low for individual teachers - they are the ones who don't have the IT backup to get round the problems that your plugins solve so elegantly! All the best Andy

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: POODLL issues on mobile and desktop
ResponsesInList.Text: That is not the latest version of PoodLL.  However the later versions are only for Moodle 2.9 and greater. But even if you did upgrade you will still experience some of those problems. Files recorded on your device will not necessarily play back in the same device's browser. For example iPhone records mov files, and Android records different file types depending on the device model. But those are mostly rotten for use in a web environment. PoodLL can't do much about that, except to receive the recordings and then convert them to a better format. You will need to convert them using FFMPEG to a file format that can be played back generically. By email last year I sent you notes on the FFMPEG setup. The javascript whiteboards should work, but there were issues in Moodle 2.8 with Literally Canvas, so please try drawingboard.js. It is one of the options in the PoodLL filter settings. Regarding being logged out when trying to upload, I have heard of this but have not had a chance to look into yet. Justin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Upload error
ResponsesInList.Text: This seems to be caused by incorrect file permissions on the PoodLL filter directory and possibly the other plugin directories too. Folders should be 755 and files 644. I have seen it a few times now and am still not sure how it comes about. Because the file permissions are correct when they leave PoodLL HQ, but somehow when they arrive on people's servers  they occasionally end up wrong. I suspect that in order to use Moodle's automatic plugin installer people change their file permissions to allow write access. If you use Filezilla FTP client , or something similar, a simple way to do this is to right click the poodll plugin folder and choose "file permissions" and then recursively change directory permissions to 755. Then recursively change file permissions to 644. As in the following screenshot:

Audio recording works on desktop browsers out of the box (except for Firefox , which needs flash in "unprotected mode")  but on mobile devices recorded files upload without a file extension (e.g. "upfile_121212."), which obviously causes all sorts of problems (also they still seem to be AAC MPEG 4). The video recorder works on mobile devices (probably because they directly output mp4) but on desktop we experienced some strange behaviour and I wanted to ask how this might happen: when opening the video recorder, there is a red cross in the lower left corner and the video controls are deactivated/greyed out. After some googling around I learned that this means that PoodLL can't connect to a Red5 Server . As soon as I type in the defaults (tokyo.poodll.com) the controls light up and I can record. It then says "cannot convert locally" or something like that and I guess that this has to do with some less than optimal FFMPEG config on our end (it's a unix server). My questions: 1) Could the missing file name extension be related to our FFMPEG not working correctly ? (the file not being MPEG Layer 3 obviously is) 2) Due to privacy concerns from our computing center we can't have any external servers listed in the application configuration. Will the controls in the video recorder work when our FFMPEG is responding correctly (but i guess the flash plugin doesn't check that beforehand)?. If we use local conversion, we shouldn't need to enter a Red5 server to click on "record", right? The whiteboard and screenshot are working fine on our test system right now and we're not using anything else. It would be great if someone could help us out here! Thanks for the great plugin and best wishes from Germany, Felix

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: FFMPEG conversion without tokyo.poodll.com
ResponsesInList.Text: This is all probably related to an FFMPEG setup that is not working properly. Its a bit hard to say without logging in  and poking around, especially the missing file extension is a bit dodgy.  But mobile devices and how they upload is a bit of a minefield and depends a lot on the device, browser and versions. PoodLL can probably handle it regardless if you specify the FFMPEG conversion parameters ... provided FFMPEG is working. The video recording relies on a Red5 server, and tokyo.poodll.com is the one that most people use. FFMPEG working or not, the video recording goes via Red5 (for desktop machines) so the greyed out controls and red cross won't be solved by fixing FFMPEG. You will need a working red5 server with PoodLL installed on it.  You can set up your own to get around privacy restrictions, but its a bit a technical.  I have attached 2 PDFs,  a "how to" on RED5 + PoodLL set up and a "how to" for FFMPEG + PoodLL set up. If you want me to do the setup, then it becomes a commercial discussion and those  need to take place off-forum. So message me in that case.

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL for Moodle 3
ResponsesInList.Text: PoodLL for Moodle 3 is now ready. My apologies for the delay. Most of it was done long ago, but it took time to get the javascript whiteboards ready and I took the opportunity to clean up a lot of old code in the PoodLL filter. The current release is for Moodle 2.9.x and 3.0.x only. Because of the code cleanup, all the PoodLL plugins will need to be updated. If you are using Git to update your plugins, each of the plugins has a branch called MOODLE_29+ . This is the correct and most up to date version for Moodle 2.9.x and 3.0.x. From now on avoid using the "master" branch. Finally PoodLL now requires the site admin to register their PoodLL. There is no charge for this at this stage, and its simply a matter a getting a registration code by filling in a form, and check ing email. A registration code can be obtained at: http://poodll.com/registration

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL for Moodle 3
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, Thanks for the good work and this new version Just some questions about registration: is it possible to use service name (and not personnal name)? if one has several Moodle sites, i imagine it's required to make a registration per site? for the URL , is trailing slash required/optional/to avoid? and so, is it possible to register multiple sites with the same ("personnal") information, just modifying URL? Some other questions about evolution of PoodLL: i know you plan to make PoodLL paying ; do you have precise date? an idea of the cost? and some precision about paying possibilities (because i know it's sometimes complicated for french universities)? will PoodLL sites already registered continue to have PoodLL functionnal when it's the case? will paying be required to use PoodLL, or will allow to have additionnal capabilities? All these questions to better know what you plan, and what can be done for us... Séverin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL for Moodle 3
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Severin If you wish to use a service name, that is ok. The current registration process is very simple. You can use the same registration key on multiple sites.  The site url is for reference at this stage, but please leave the trailing slash off. The purpose of requiring people to register, is so that I can contact the right people about PoodLL developments. These communications will not be often. They will likely  be information about upcoming releases, broken functionality,  questions about PoodLL usage, but there will be news about commercial matters too. I had planned to impose a paywall on this version of PoodLL but I was worried that the word had really not gotten out about that. And as you mention, we need to give institutions fair lead time for this sort of thing. So it seemed too abrupt and the lack of a PoodLL for Moodle 3 was preventing people upgrading. So I decided to simply require registration so that I could communicate with the key people to manage the transition more smoothly. The current version of PoodLL will remain available indefinitely (and any security/bug fixes). Later versions will be premium.  Any new release from now on will be premium. I am estimating that institutions will pay $US800 per year, but I want to keep the option available for individual teachers to continue to use PoodLL.. I am still thinking through how best to do that. The revenue will pay for more reliable release dates that match those of Moodle. And it will pay for the addition of a host of new features. The plan is to hire some help for those. The wishlist includes: Cloud hosting of PoodLL recordings Cloud hosting of media files HTML5 audio and video recorders HTML5 audio and video players HTML5 snapshots Contributions to the Literally Canvas whiteboard codebase A mobile application for PoodLL Data logging on all aspects of PoodLL use Multiple education purposed  HTML5 audio players (once players, mini players, subtitle players) An audio recorder with built in shadowing and mirroring functions Full HTML5 and audio enabled flashcards Skinnable audio and video recorders An html5 widgets icon for the Atto editor Almost none of this will be available immediately however. It is something to look forward to!

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Red5 server setup?
ResponsesInList.Text: You should check the red5.properties (?) file in the red5 config directory. You can see there which ports the server is set up to listen on for which services. As long as the PoodLL filter settings match what is there it should work. I think from what you posted the http port is currently 5080 but I do not know what the RTMPT port is. Possibly it is not enabled yet. If you don't need RTMPT, then don't worry about it. Try putting 5080 into your poodll filter settings http port setting, and see if it works Ideally the RTMPT port should be 80 or 443. That is because for bypassing firewalls, those two ports are  usually open. The http port is for moodle server to red5 server communications (ie downloading the recorded file). If both machines are on the same network then you don't have to worry about firewall issues, and even a high port will work ok.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Red5 server setup?

Now I set the redirection from 5080 to 5080 and everything work perfect. I suppose, that red5 cannot handle this kind of redirection.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Red5 server setup?
ResponsesInList.Text: Port redirection would take place at the networking level, and Red5 would not even know about it ..... I think. But if you have it working, great!

ResponsesInList.Title: An error occured, your file has NOT been submitted
ResponsesInList.Text: Nobody likes to see this. But what should you check when it happens? Well first of all its a general error. And it tells you/the student that your recording will not be saved. That is important. At this point your recording is already gone. There is probably nothing you can do but re record. Things to check i) is the microphone capturing sound? Or the video camera capturing your picture. If not, then there is nothing to submit or convert. And you might get this error. ii) does a very short recording get submitted ok? Sometimes longer recordings have problems at the server or browser level. iii) what recorder are you using? The two audio recorders look similar but are completely different. The video one is different again but in terms of troubleshooting its identical to the red5 audio recorder. MP3 recorder: recordings get less reliable as they get longer. Best not to venture over 2 mins. conversion to MP3 happens before the upload . If the file is too big it might spin forever and give up if the upload begins but throws an error, the connection to the Moodle server is problematic. Check the browser console for errors related to the file being posted. Some servers restrict the upload file size. Thats a whole new ball game, but if thats the case small uploads will be working. audio recorder/video recorder (red5): if you can't play it back after recording.... then the file never arrived on the Red5 server. Check the connection lamp on the recorder. Should be green. If its red or yellow your connection is bad (firewall? ) or the red5 server is down (happens.) If you can play it back, but get the error message above ... then the problem is that your file can't be collected from the Red5 server and copied back into Moodle. Turn off auto convert to mp3/mp4 in the filter settings and try again (or uncheck the mp3/mp4 checkbox on the recorder BEFORE recording). If conversion is the issue then its best to set up FFMPEG on the Moodle server and have PoodLL do its magic with that. Check the port settings in the PoodLL filter settings for HTTP. Your Moodle server will need to be able to do a server to server connection to that port on the  Red5 server to pick up the recorded file.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: An error occured, your file has NOT been submitted
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, I have a student who claims the PoodLL MP3 recorder does not pick up his microphone (which, he claims, works fine otherwise). He can save recordings, but they have zero length and thus do not play. He claims to have tried different browsers, different microphone settings and has the latest version of Flash. Can you give a suggestion as to what I might look into. The others in the course manage to record. Rgrds, Paul.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: An error occured, your file has NOT been submitted
ResponsesInList.Text: I think your student has probably unwittingly denied permission to the recorder to access the microphone. Depending on the browser there are two places permissions need to be granted. Flash will show a permissions dialog which can be reshown by right clicking over the recorder and selecting "settings" or "properties". Chrome and other browsers may have their own permissions dialogs which will be shown after flash tries to access the mic. Other things to check might include that the microphone is plugged in, or if there are multiple microphones in the machine, that the correct one is selected. (again right click ->settings and choose the microphone tab ). Occasionally it is necessary to mess with the microphone tab settings there to spark the microphone into action. I do not know why. Flash is a black box in that regard.

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: I've been using the PoodLL mp3 audio recorder in the Atto text editor on my Moodle 2.9 system and the recording seems to go fine. I save it and whenever I go to play it back, I usually only get an audio clip of 4 to 12 seconds long, even if the recording was a minute or two. Does anyone have any suggestions or solutions?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: I have seen this before, and I am trying to recall what caused it. It may be a PHP thing called Suhosin interfering with your uploaded audio data. Go to site admin -> server ->php info. Do a search (ctrl + f) for 'suhosin' and also look at 'post_max_size' and 'upload_max_filesize.' If suhosin is there, it is the most likely culprit. And you will need to configure it to accept larger upload sizes. If its not there, then its nor the problem. If either of the other 2 values are really small, ie less than 2M, then that might be the problem. But thats unlikely.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: I checked to see if suhosin was there but it's not. The post_max_size and upload_max_filesize are both 1024M. It's strange because the video recorder for example works perfectly. I've recorded up too 3 minutes of video and it all comes up when it's saved.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: The Video and Red5 audio recorders work very differently to the MP3 recorder. So its not so surprising the behaviour is different. The MP3 recorder posts the data to the server, which the other recorders don't do. Something is truncating the uploaded data. I am not sure what is doing it, but anything that limits the upload file size would be something to look at. If it works for you, you might try using the Red5 audio recorder as a workaround

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: I'll give the Red5 recorder a try but I seem to remember a similar problem with it. When you say server, do you mean the tokyo.poodll.com server? Do you think installing FFMPEG might help with this issue?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: Installing FFMPEG , and configuring PoodLL to use it, is a good thing to do. But that is really about file conversion. And I don't think that is a solution to this problem. Something is limiting the file upload size on your Moodle server. There is no "upload" from browser to Moodle server when using tokyo.poodll.com. The browser uploads to tokyo.poodll.com. And then your Moodle server downloads it from there. That is why it is unaffected.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL audio recording cuts off early
ResponsesInList.Text: Ok, that makes sense. I'll talk to our Moodle host and ask them to investigate if there's something limiting the upload size. Thanks for your help Justin, it really is a great plugin.

Sorry, the news is not better, AL

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL in Journal(Plugin)?
ResponsesInList.Text: I have no update on this. But we should define "this." If the html area does not allow file uploads, then there is nowhere to store audio/video recordings. So PoodLL Anywhere hides itself. To avoid people wasting their time trying to record something that won't be saved anywhere accessible. "this" is a new system to store poodll recordings optionally in off-moodle storage, like dropbox or Google drive or box. Its not ready yet. I will do it soon. But no promises as to when.

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL Issues
ResponsesInList.Text: An instructor asked students to use the voice recorder enabled for them via PoodLL's plug-in within Moodle. One of the biggest problems is that it was very confusing for students because they couldn't tell if their audio actually submitted, as no notification was given, and after saving, they can't see the file there, or listen back to it. The instructor had the same problem in leaving voice feedback for students. Is there anyway for students and instructors to listen to files after they've been submitted? Or for instance if an instructor uses PoodLL to give feedback and two weeks later wants to hear it to remember what they said can they? Currently that doesn't seem available.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: PoodLL Issues
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Clint That should certainly be possible. I wonder how you are doing these things. Perhaps you are doing it a different way than most, or the recording is not working at all. The recorder does allow you to playback the recorded file, and should display an "uploading" dialog. And after the page hosting the recorder has been saved, there should be a player (audio or video) in the feedback area for the student ( or on the submission summary if its an assignment submission). And when the teacher returns to the page they should see a recorder for re-recording and a player for listening to the existing feedback recording. If none of that is happening, it should be, and so there is some problem at your end.

ResponsesInList.Title: Community Feedback on Poodll Accessibility?
ResponsesInList.Text: Our program is considering the Poodll Plug-ins, and one critical requirement we have of our coursework is accessibility . I am interested in the community's feedback on Poodll's usability and functions for people who are visually or hearing impaired. Putting aside the complications of audio and video assignments and feedback for a moment (we know we have a lot of work to help class members and instructors provide accessible content for each other ), please comment on the usability of the tools themselves. From the videos I am seen of Poodll in action the buttons and links appear as accessible or inaccessible as any other Moodle module.  Do you or your users report a different experience? Thanks for your thoughts. Robin Sitten Perkins eLearning

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Community Feedback on Poodll Accessibility?
ResponsesInList.Text: Robin, it would be interesting indeed to see what others have to say on this. But I have to say that it is probably not the best news. I battled for some time to make the buttons visible to screen readers and in the end found that it was not going to work ... because of limitations of the framework I originally wrote the recorders in. Though it did not occur to me then, since that time I have found a way around those limitations and have implemented it in one of the recorders. Basically by hiding the flash widget and handling all user interaction via html buttons and javascript a far more accessible interface can be made. Effectively we are introducing skinning to PoodLL. It is just a matter of finding the time, to get it all done. But accessibility goes beyond just screen readers, so any comments or advice would be welcome.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Community Feedback on Poodll Accessibility?
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Robin, I was just browsing information about Poodll on Moodle.or and found your post and one other which didn't seem to address the issue. I've been working on Poodll in Moodle 2.8 and found that this plugin is not accessible. When I ran the NVDA screen reader and also sent a sample to our disability officer which is blind, he was unable to detect the player. The screen reader bypasses this alltogether. I will be sending a request to the developers to review this plug in and help us to comply with WCAG 2.0. Cheers, Nora Colazzo

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Community Feedback on Poodll Accessibility?
ResponsesInList.Text: You are right that much of it is not accessible. Luckily its not far away for the most popular of the components however. I was able to introduce full skinning for the MP3 audio recorder last month, thanks to "The Learning Factory" in Brazil. That makes adding accessibility to the MP3 recorder relatively simple. The other recorders require similar work, but at least we have a pattern to go with. The part that is not simple in all this for me, is exactly what the normal/desired behaviour of an screen reader, especially when it encounters an audio recorder. I was quite puzzled when I was testing with JAWS previously.

ResponsesInList.Title: PoodLL and Flash
ResponsesInList.Text: Yesterday Adobe Flash was getting death threats from Facebook and getting blocked by Firefox , after news of not just security errors, but in the wild exploits,  came to light. PoodLL uses Adobe Flash mainly for audio/video recording, but it can be turned off if need be. Flash can also be turned off for the widgets, players and whiteboards. Information on how to do that is here: http://poodll.com/flash-and-poodll/ In short, in the PoodLL filter settings, widgets, players and recorders can be limited to HTML5 only in the "When to use HTML5" section. The default whiteboard can be selected in the "Whiteboard settings" section. N.B. The non flash whiteboards (LiterallyCanvas and DrawingBoard.js) are not working properly in Moodle 2.9 yet. I am not actually advising anyone to turn Flash off. I will leave that to people more knowledgeable than me. But if you are in a situation where you cannot use Flash, the above settings should do the job.

ResponsesInList.Title: Android Mp3 recordings do not playback on PC web navigators

When I record from an Android device (Samsung Galaxy S3 with Android 4.x and Chrome) and try to playback it on my PC (Chrome, Firefox or IE11), there is no playback. It's as if there was no recording at all. I'm able to reproduce this on Moodle 2.8.6 with the Atto editor and also TinyMCE. Also, the problem never occurs with pictures or videos. Did I miss something?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Android Mp3 recordings do not playback on PC web navigators
ResponsesInList.Text: Are you sure that the mp3 recordings are really MP3? It sounds like the Android recordings are in a different format (3GP?) that most PCs can't playback. The best way to deal with this is to install FFMPEG on your server and set PoodLL to autoconvert incoming audio uploads to MP3. If you are not sure can you attach one of the recordings to a reply on this post, and I will look at it. There is a setting in the PoodLL filter settings which will show a download icon beside the player (for admins). I posted a screenshot of that.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Android Mp3 recordings do not playback on PC web navigators
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Justin, Thanks for the tip. I forgot that Android devices generates a .m4a format. I will ask my colleagues if they are willing to try your solution. Regards, Melvin

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Installation and / or Flashcard Problems
ResponsesInList.Text: If you see back and next buttons but no cards, then PoodLL can not find a data source for the card content. The simplest way these days is to add a: qname=mymatchingquestionname attribute in the filter string. If you have a matching question of that name it will use that for the data source. If you can't make it work, post your string here and let me look at it.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to enable TinyMCE Editor.
ResponsesInList.Text: Moodle has both the TinyMCE editor and the Atto editor. From Moodle 2.7 onwards Atto has been the default. PoodLL Anywhere can work with either, but has a separate plugin for each. The instructions for each should explain how to install them and set them up. You have installed PoodLL Anywhere for TinyMCE. So you could install PoodLL Anywhere for Atto , or enable the TinyMCE editor. If you are currently using Atto and you want to change to enable TinyMCE, that is done at: site administration->plugins->text editors->manage editors (I attached a screenshot)

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: How to enable TinyMCE Editor : How to use
ResponsesInList.Text: I don't think what you ask is possible without customizing something. This is because PoodLL has to save the files in the file area for the html editor. If file attachments are not enabled, there is no file area to store the files. That is why PoodLL hides itself. However there is a PoodLL Recording question type. If you install this, and use it instead of the essay question type, you can accept voice recordings as answers. https://moodle.org/plugins/view/qtype_poodllrecording

ResponsesInList.Text: I've been trying to set up a PoodLL webapp Justin gave me for my Red5 server and I'm stuck. The recording works fine and will playback on my desktop computer but always fails to upload . The picture shows the actual error. Anyone have any idea what might be the problem?

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Video file fails to upload
ResponsesInList.Text: Hi Al If it plays back ok, then the Red5 connection is ok. But what is not ok is when Moodle tries to copy the file back into Moodle's file system Check these things: i) the location of the recorded file. It should be in the dir specified in /webapps/poodll/WEB-INF/red-properties. xml (need trailing slash) ii) the port on which Moodle is trying to connect to copy the file. this is 443 by default, but if Red5 and Moodle are on the same server then Apache is probably hogging port 443. So try 5080. Either way check that the port is actually matched on the Red5 side. To do that go into red5/conf/red5.properties. The HTTP port is the one that needs to match. (RTMP is probably ok with 1935. RTMPT is also interesting but it won't cause the problems you are describing. It is the port to use tunnel RTMP connections through a firewall.) Also don't auto convert files to mp4 or mp3 while testing. Conversion is another place where things can go wrong. When you get to that stage, use FFMPEG to do the conversion in Moodle. I have another document on setting all that up somewhere.

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll on ipad

The repository is the system you go through using the regular moodle media button (ie choosing from google docs, youtube, wikimedia, upload a file etc) You can use FFMPEG on your Moodle server to auto convert uploaded files to MP4. I am pretty sure you have not set up that, so I think we can ignore that avenue. Let me know if I am wrong though. So the files Moodle is attempting to play will be .mov files. Flowplayer should play those back fine. As of course, should the iPad. But I have seen it go wrong. I would really need to see the uploaded file to check. So here are two things to try. i) turn off the PoodLL filter, and try to reload the page and play the video. Does it work? If so, PoodLL is messing up the playback somehow. If it still doesn't play .. lets do ii) ii) Turn the poodll filter back on. And turn on "show download link" beside players  in the PoodLL filter settings. Then there should be a download link by the player when the page is loaded. Download the file to your desktop. Can you play it there? ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll on ipad
ResponsesInList.Text: Eric That .mov file was empty, and that is the heart of the problem. I don't like asking you to jump through all these hoops, but here are two more. Sorry. Can you try the same thing into the "forum(with video)" activity on http://demo.poodll.com ? (login creds are on the front page ) If it works there, it is a server specific thingy we need to figure out. There might be an error in your logs. If you can find the error log that apache generates, check it and see if there are any recent errors that look related. It can be necessary to turn off or configure a thing called Suhosin. And your server's maximum file upload size could also be a part of the problem. If we are at this point and there is no good error in your server logs, it gets quite complicated unfortunately. If it doesn't work on demo.poodll.com I think that maybe PoodLL has in issue with receiving uploads from your ipad. One thing that I have seen occur, is when people select "choose existing video" from the popup dialog, rather than "take a video." The uploaded file is compressed and this can cause problems with the browser/server interaction. The best reply right now to this is to recommend people select "take a video."

ResponsesInList.Title: Re: Poodll on ipad
ResponsesInList.Text: I know that this is very late (happened upon it while reading about Poodll), but the upside-down video may just be that the ipad/iphone was being held "upside down" when taking the video. My understanding is that the camera has a definite orientation (Home button should be either down for portrait orientation or on right for landscape), but will flip the preview of the video or photo if held upside down. This flipping will continue if viewing the photo or video on an Apple device. When viewed on other systems - that don't read or understand the encoded "flip this image" instructions, the image is displayed as it was recorded - upside down. This became more of a problem when Apple enabled the volume buttons to act as the shutter release. This made it more natural to hold the phone with the shutter release (volume) on top - like a camera. Which is really upside-down. David
